trans-unit.source: Automatically generates single-table commands used to reconcile changes made to a <xref href="System.Data.DataSet"></xref> with the associated database.
This class cannot be inherited.
This type is deprecated and will be removed in a future version of the .NET Framework.
For more information, see [Oracle and ADO.NET](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).

The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> does not automatically generate the SQL statements required to reconcile changes made to a <xref:System.Data.DataSet> associated with the database.

However, you can create an OracleCommandBuilder object that generates SQL statements for single-table updates by setting the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.SelectCommand%2A> property of the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>.
Then, the OracleCommandBuilder generates any additional SQL statements that you do not set.
The relationship between an <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> and its corresponding OracleCommandBuilder is always one-to-one.
To create this correspondence, you set the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> property of the OracleCommandBuilder object.

This causes the OracleCommandBuilder to register itself as a listener, which produces the output of <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.RowUpdating> events that affect the <xref:System.Data.DataSet>.
To generate INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statements, the OracleCommandBuilder uses the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.SelectCommand%2A> property to retrieve a required set of metadata.

The OracleCommandBuilder also uses the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.Connection%2A>, and <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.Transaction%2A> properties referenced by the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.SelectCommand%2A>.

If you call <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataAdapter.Dispose%2A>, the OracleCommandBuilder is disassociated from the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>, and the generated commands are no longer used.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder"></xref>.

The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> registers itself as a listener for <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.RowUpdating> events that are generated by the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> specified in this property.

When you create a new instance of <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder>, any existing <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> associated with this <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> is released.
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder"></xref> class with the associated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter"></xref> object.

The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> registers itself as a listener for <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.RowUpdating> events that are generated by the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> specified in this property.

When you create a new instance of <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder>, any existing <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> associated with this <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> is released.
An <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter"></xref> object to associate with this <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder"></xref>.
To be added.
To be added.
To be added.
To be added.
Sets or gets the <xref href="System.Data.Common.CatalogLocation"></xref> for an instance of the <xref href="System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder"></xref> class.
A <xref href="System.Data.Common.CatalogLocation"></xref> object.
Sets or gets a string used as the catalog separator for an instance of the <xref href="System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder"></xref> class.
A string indicating the catalog separator for use with an instance of the <xref href="System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder"></xref> class.

Gets or sets an <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter"></xref> object for which this <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder"></xref> object will generate SQL statements.

The <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> registers itself as a listener for <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter.RowUpdating> events that are generated by the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> specified in this property.

When you create a new instance of <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder>, any existing <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder> associated with this <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter> is released.
An <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter"></xref> object that is associated with this <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder"></xref>.

Retrieves parameter information from the stored procedure specified in the <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> and populates the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.Parameters*> collection of the specified <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object.
DeriveParameters overwrites any existing parameter information for the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand>.
DeriveParameters requires an extra call to the database to obtain the information.
If the parameter information is known in advance, it is more efficient to populate the parameters collection by setting the information explicitly.
You can only use DeriveParameters with stored procedures.
You cannot use DeriveParameters to populate the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleParameterCollection> with arbitrary Transact-SQL statements, such as a parameterized SELECT statement.
For more information, see [Configuring Parameters and Parameter Data Types](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> referencing the stored procedure from which the parameter information is to be derived.
The derived parameters are added to the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.Parameters*> collection of the <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref>.
The command text is not a valid stored procedure name, or the <xref href="System.Data.CommandType"></xref> specified was not <xref href="System.Data.CommandType"></xref>.
Gets the automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform deletions on the database.
You can use the GetDeleteCommand method for informational or troubleshooting purposes because it returns the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> object to be executed.
You can also use GetDeleteCommand as the basis of a modified command.

For example, you might call GetDeleteCommand and modify the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.CommandText%2A> value, and then explicitly set that on the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>.
The SQL statements are first generated when the application calls either <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataAdapter.Update%2A> or GetDeleteCommand.
For more information, see [Generating Commands with CommandBuilders](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform deletions.
Gets the automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform deletions on the database.

You can use the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetDeleteCommand%2A> method for informational or troubleshooting purposes because it returns the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> object to be executed.
You can also use <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetDeleteCommand%2A> as the basis of a modified command.

For example, you might call <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetDeleteCommand%2A> and modify the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.CommandText%2A> value, and then explicitly set that on the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>.
The SQL statements are first generated when the application calls either <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataAdapter.Update%2A> or <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetDeleteCommand%2A>.
The default behavior, when generating parameter names, is to use @p1, @p2, and so on for the various parameters.
Passing `true` for the `useColumnsForParameterNames` parameter allows you to force the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder> to generate parameters based on the column names instead.

This succeeds only if the following conditions are met: - The <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterNameMaxLength> has been specified and its length is equal to or greater than the generated parameter name.
- The generated parameter name meets the criteria specified in the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterNamePattern> regular expression.
- A <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterMarkerFormat> is specified.
For more information, see [Generating Commands with CommandBuilders](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
If true, generate parameter names matching column names, if possible.
If false, generate @p1, @p2, and so on.
The automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform deletions.
Gets the automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform insertions on the database.
You can use the GetInsertCommand method for informational or troubleshooting purposes because it returns the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> object to be executed.
You can also use GetInsertCommand as the basis of a modified command.

For example, you might call GetInsertCommand and modify the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.CommandText%2A> value, and then explicitly set that on the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>.
The SQL statements are first generated when the application calls either <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataAdapter.Update%2A> or GetInsertCommand.
For more information, see [Generating Commands with CommandBuilders](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
The automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform insertions.
Gets the automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform insertions on the database.

You can use the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetInsertCommand%2A> method for informational or troubleshooting purposes because it returns the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> object to be executed.
You can also use <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetInsertCommand%2A> as the basis of a modified command.

For example, you might call <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetInsertCommand%2A> and modify the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.CommandText%2A> value, and then explicitly set that on the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>.
The SQL statements are first generated when the application calls either <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataAdapter.Update%2A> or <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetInsertCommand%2A>.
The default behavior, when generating parameter names, is to use @p1, @p2, and so on for the various parameters.
Passing `true` for the `useColumnsForParameterNames` parameter allows you to force the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder> to generate parameters based on the column names instead.

This succeeds only if the following conditions are met: - The <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterNameMaxLength> has been specified and its length is equal to or greater than the generated parameter name.
- The generated parameter name meets the criteria specified in the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterNamePattern> regular expression.
- A <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterMarkerFormat> is specified.
For more information, see [Generating Commands with CommandBuilders](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
If true, generate parameter names matching column names, if possible.
If false, generate @p1, @p2, and so on.
The automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform insertions.

Gets the automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform updates on the database.

You can use the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetUpdateCommand%2A> method for informational or troubleshooting purposes because it returns the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand> object to be executed.
You can also use <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetUpdateCommand%2A> as the basis of a modified command.

For example, you might call <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetUpdateCommand%2A> and modify the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand.CommandText%2A> value, and then explicitly set that on the <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleDataAdapter>.
The SQL statements are first generated when the application calls either <xref:System.Data.Common.DbDataAdapter.Update%2A> or <xref:System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommandBuilder.GetUpdateCommand%2A>.
The default behavior, when generating parameter names, is to use @p1, @p2, and so on for the various parameters.
Passing `true` for the `useColumnsForParameterNames` parameter allows you to force the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbCommandBuilder> to generate parameters based on the column names instead.

This succeeds only if the following conditions are met: - The <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterNameMaxLength> has been specified and its length is equal to or greater than the generated parameter name.
- The generated parameter name meets the criteria specified in the <xref:System.Data.Common.DbMetaDataColumnNames.ParameterNamePattern> regular expression.

For more information, see [Generating Commands with CommandBuilders](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
If true, generate parameter names matching column names, if possible.
If false, generate @p1, @p2, and so on.
The automatically generated <xref href="System.Data.OracleClient.OracleCommand"></xref> object required to perform updates.
Given an unquoted identifier in the correct catalog case, returns the correct quoted form of that identifier, including properly escaping any embedded quotes in the identifier.
The original unquoted identifier.
The quoted version of the identifier.
Embedded quotes within the identifier are properly escaped.
Gets or sets the character to be used for the separator between the schema identifier and any other identifiers.
Generally, database servers indicate the schema for a identifier by separating the schema name from the identifier with some character.
For example, SQL Server uses a colon, creating complete identifiers such as Person:CustomerName, where "Person" is the schema name and "CustomerName" is the identifier.
Setting this property allows developers to modify this behavior.
The character to be used as the schema separator.
To be added.
Given a quoted identifier, returns the correct unquoted form of that identifier, including properly un-escaping any embedded quotes in the identifier.
The identifier that will have its embedded quotes removed.
The unquoted identifier, with embedded quotes properly un-escaped.
